narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The course is clearly based on material coming focusing the US and Connecticut energy and legal framework scenario. Even if there is a global session (the last third of the course) the course is extremely limited to US focus. Although the instructor did many efforts "to keep the course global", there was a lack of global case studies and an absence of situations to put hands on practical and existing international issues on climate change. Again the course is very US (if not Connecticut) oriented. It is not enough to call on question students from different nationalities to make the "globalize" the course and align it with the global needs of climate change. The instructor should assume different perspectives on the climate change putting himself in the shoes of several countries and contexts. I found this did not happen. There is an international session but even this part is taught to students by talking of a global issue from a US filtering lens, not assuming really an international point of view.

13 Dan is an excellent professor. No frills teaching method, just him and the students and his notes. Very engaging, gets people to talk, very knowledgeable and uses real life examples to get people interested in the topics he covers each class. He is very supportive of students in class, but also pushes for a diverse set of answers, and is very approachable out of class too.

I certainly enjoyed the course and found what I learned to be quite valuable. That said, its limitations as a survey course were apparent, and its admirable attempt to combine lecture and discussion did not feel fully successful. I would have appreciated more clear and lengthy explanations of frameworks for analysis, and perhaps fewer topics covered but a bit more depth.
For FES MEM students, this is a course that should be offered and taken in the fall semester of the first year. It provides a broad overview of all the relevant issues we study.
Questions 1-4: While the reading was heavier than my other courses, I thought that the readings picked were great and very informative.
The course could benefit from a more international focus.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Overall I found the course interesting in informing students on the main issues that are nowadays related with global issue of climate change, as seen from a US perspective.
Lectures.
Conducting mid term survey and adjusting accordingly to student's feedback
The lecture material and opportunity to work on a semester-long paper.
Strong policy discussions, variety of topics and diverse background of students in class.

The readings and lecture combined provide a fantastic overview of issues of climate and energy. Dan gives great insights--though there wasn't always enough time for them to be fleshed out--and in some ways the class felt like book club with Dan Esty, which was great. Its lecture-discussion style, while not perfect, did make it a lot easier to engage with material actively (compared to a straightforward lecture course). Policy memos were also quite useful and productive exercises.
The policy memos provide practical training for the type of writing expected in the real world.
Discussion, policy memos

I really enjoyed learning about a broad range of topics pertaining to climate change and clean energy from an expert in the field. Dan did a wonderful job of providing concise, relevant, and insightful information about everything we covered in the course.
The best aspect of this course was the opportunity to cover a wide breadth of environmental, climate, and energy topics and devote considerable time to thinking about the issues.
covered extensive material, very topical issues discussed, very instructor focused as opposed to powerpoints, etc
The class discussion
I thought that the combination of lecture, classroom discussion, readings, and short response papers was great. I think that all aspects of the course complemented each other.

Material was very relevant and the methods with which we were assessed translate very well to real world skills that will be required in the future. Course was very current and adapted to changing events.
This course provided a very comprehensive background of energy and climate change.
Gave an overview of the world's climate change initiatives by all nations, what has worked and what has failed so far.
Assignments were very useful. Readings were all terrific. Overall excellent course.

This was one of my favorite courses at Yale! The lectures were clear and straightforward. We wrote 3 policy memos over the course of the semester, which helped focus my writing. Great intro level energy course.
It covers many relevant issues related to climate change and clean energy, giving a great overall view of this topics.

1. Policy Memos- Useful and practical. 2. Course structure and readings- Excellent and very well researched. 3. Lecture sessions- Were very engaging. This course was perhaps one of the few at FES which provided an opportunity for the integration of diverse global perspectives in class lecture. I gleaned a lot from from fellow students who had some form of expertise in particular aspects of the course. 4. Current and in tune with real time events in energy and climate governance, such as the supreme court ruling on the CPP and the December 2015 Paris Agreement.
Dan's teaching style was the best aspect of this course. He was successfully encouraged students to actively involved in class' discussions
the class discussion were extremely helpful

Really enjoyed the scope of the course and the context it was put into. Also - the fact that current events were often brought up and analyzed alongside the historical topics we covered made the course very valuable.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Climate change is a global issue. This course should add international (non US based) case studies and offer team work activities by selecting groups of international students. Also the Instructor should make an effort to detach from his "US capitalist" filtered view on climate change and assume different perspective when it comes to the global aspect of the issue. But I know, it is not easy to do!
May need lectures slides AND a reasonable amounts of readings for each session

I certainly enjoyed the course and found what I learned to be quite valuable. That said, its limitations as a survey course were apparent, and its admirable attempt to combine lecture and discussion did not feel fully successful. I would have appreciated more clear and lengthy explanations of frameworks for analysis, and perhaps fewer topics covered but a bit more depth. I also am unsure how to feel about the take-home final, which was portrayed as a way to explore ideas with intellectual vigor, but was constrained in time (justifiably, I suppose) and, more importantly, discussion of the exam with peers was forbidden. Though that makes sense in the context of an exam, it is not conducive to the intellectual exploration I would have found more fulfilling getting out of the exam and the course.
More guidance on policy memo writing at the beginning of the semester, more explanation of participation grade, cover more developing countries, too many readings

The class is designed to be more of a survey course than a seminar. Perhaps next year, Dan could limit the size of the course to provide for more fruitful discussion and offer a larger lecture course to complement the seminar course.
The readings and course content were at times repetitive. Dan also selectively focused on certain issues, while I would have appreciated greater breadth of coverage.
Perhaps more basic technical concepts of energy issues, which many lack. And also perhaps a field trip or group discussions and more debates.
Having a better understanding of how to write a good memo in the beginning of class would be beneficial.
Would be better as a seminar instead of a lecture. These topics lend themselves well to discussion and critical thinking, not simply being told.
More depth and international perspective.
Esty tends to talk a lot about CT and his prior position as Commissioner at DEEP.
There is too much reading material.

Professor's Esty's talents are fallow without a tad bit of environmental case and statutory law. Many of us would have loved to hear him dive into the leaves of the CAA or Clean Power Plan, not simply wave his hand at the forest. His lucid contextual narratives should eradicate any fear of the course estranging talented people/potential advocates lacking prior experience (especially if case briefs do not bear the burden of including such analysis in their scant pages).

While the course is one of the few truly global courses at FES, I sometimes felt that lectures and class discussions on some topics lacked balance and/or were not fully exhaustive. Specifically, the lectures on Climate Equity, Climate Adaptation and the Climate Governance role of some international organisations.
More portion in course materials on developing countries would be great.
There need to be a broader international outlook

I would say that in some instances, the technical gap of some students led to unproductive conversations. For example, a basic overview of the carbon cycle could have benefited a few of the energy policy lectures (e.g. carbon sequestration).

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section was not effective and it could be improved. For instance I found the material provided to prepare for each class, particularly the readings, very disconnected from the lecture. It can be said that this was done on porpouse to stimulate the critical skills of students to look around for other sources and have a variety of view on the topics. This fact has already happened to me in other courses. But in Climate Change and Clean Energy I found the readings poorly aligned with the lecture. Not excuses to defend them. To improve the readings should better selected. Also take new readings!! Many of them were dated around 2000!!!

There were no discussion sections, which I think should be considered. I'm unsure whether I would have gotten much more out of discussion sections, but it certainly seemed like some other, more concrete forum beyond class could have improved the experience.
Very effective.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I'm not a YLS/FES student. I think this is a very relevant topic to a lot of professions, specifically in my case business and policy. Climate change and the future of clean energy is increasingly a topic of discussion in policy arenas as well as within corporations and this class gives you nice overview of the field and main debates.

Going into climate change mitigation in developing countries and this was a great survey of the pertinent issues and debates and a good review of what makes good policy.
This course provided me with a broad overview of the topics relevant to discussions of climate change today.
Climate change is one of my main areas of interest, a very relevant topic in the present, and an essential issue to consider when thinking about building a more sustainable world.

My focus is on climate and energy. This course ranked high among courses I took this semester. It provided both a primer for topics I was not well versed with - such as domestic energy policy - and a discussion platform to share knowledge from past experiences working in the climate policy through class discussions. The course was excellent and readings well researched and current. This provided multiple interdisciplinary learning opportunities. I was able to apply knowledge from this class to other classes and vice versa.
The course fits into my overall program on environmental field. The course gave a strong foundation on climate change and energy sector
I am taking a water specialization and water is major resource affected by climate change and important in energy production

I am an engineer, so I'm probably coming at the course from a more technical standpoint. However, this course was thus very valuable because it gave me the background and vocabulary to understand and follow policy. My current research studies the impact on water by hydraulic fracturing, so I predict that the policy background will come in handy for both my research and my future career!

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: The course does not really give you a global view on climate change issues. The course provide instead a great summary of global issues on climate change as seen from the US perspective. This course is far away from being global!

Take this course if you want a broad overview of an very relevant and hot topic; climate change and clean energy. Dan is an amazing instructor, and the way the course is structured is great. It is at a high level so you don't need background in this topic - yet it requires you to delve deep into topics of choice (via policy memos and the final exam).
Be ready to write, write and write

I'd recommend going with the paper option rather than the exam option. Also, I enjoyed sitting and listening to the lecture rather than feverishly typing out notes, and would recommend a similar approach.

This course is an overview of issues of climate and energy, focused on policy and "Comparative Institutional Analysis." It is definitely a broad survey course--depth is not its forte, but it gives good background on many topics. The course requires 3 short policy memos, which are manageable and quite useful to learn how to write. Beyond that, readings are manageable, though at times quite long and not always engaging. The course has a take-home final, which I recommend not procrastinating. I'd say the course is worth taking, and manageable even if you don't have a lot of background in the subject, though most of your classmates would. I also wouldn't expect everything to be super clear or concrete, but I recommend visiting office hours (and Dan's office hours) more than I did, which I think would help.
Take the course in your first year.
There is a lot of reading for this course, so make sure you give yourself enough time to get through what readings may be most useful for you.
Take it!! You won't regret it.
Take it absolutely!
Be ready to participate in the class discussion

Definitely take this course. It may be a bit of reading, but it's a worthwhile set of readings that are very actively discussed in class. The fact that the course is Law/FES is really unique and helps provide unique perspective. Along with this, the students are from a variety of schools (Law, FES, SOM, Jackson) which adds color to classroom discussion.

This course is a comprehensive survey of climate change and clean energy issues and policies internationally and domestically.

I'd advise students to target their policy briefs toward realms of Clean Energy with which they have the least facility, and to reserve depth in their focal area for the term paper. As a development economist, I had an epiphany regarding Environmental Communication prompted by an Esty deadline forcing me to write on the topic, and I am so thankful for the serendipity that opened my eyes to the topic. I hope for the same for you.

Climate and Clean Energy is an ideal survey course for anyone interested in exploring the inter-linkages between energy and climate. The course also provides useful insights into global climate governance (policy & legal). I highly recommend this course for international students seeking to gain an understanding of domestic energy & climate policy.
